title: AB 1678
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 6228 of the Family Code is amended to require state and local law enforcement agencies to provide incident reports to victims of domestic violence, sexual assault, stalking, human trafficking, or abuse of an elder without charging a fee. A copy of an incident report face sheet must be provided to a victim or their representative within 48 hours of the request, unless there is a valid reason for delay, in which case it must be provided within five working days. A victim or their representative must be provided with a copy of the incident report within five working days of the request, unless there is a valid reason for delay, in which case it must be provided within 10 working days. (c) To request copies of domestic violence face sheets or incident reports, a person must provide state or local law enforcement with identification such as a driver's license, state ID, or passport. If the person is a representative of a deceased victim, they must also show a certified copy of the death certificate. If the victim is alive and not under conservatorship, the representative must present a written authorization signed by the victim. This applies to requests made within five years of the incident report completion. The Access to Domestic Violence Reports Act of 1999 applies to requests for sexual assault, stalking, human trafficking, or abuse of an elder or dependent adult face sheets or incident reports made within two years. The definition of "victim" includes minors aged 12 or older. If the victim is deceased, a "representative of the victim" can be the surviving spouse, child over 18, domestic partner, surviving parent, adult relative, personal representative, or public administrator. The Access to Domestic Violence Reports Act of 1999 applies to requests for sexual assault, stalking, human trafficking, or abuse of an elder or dependent adult face sheets or incident reports made within two years. The definition of "victim" includes minors aged 12 or older. A "representative of the victim" can be a parent, guardian, adult child, adult sibling, attorney, or conservator who presents proper identification and documentation to law enforcement. The Access to Domestic Violence Reports Act of 1999 applies to requests for certain incident reports within two years. A representative of the victim excludes individuals convicted of first-degree murder of the victim or identified as a suspect. Reimbursement for mandated costs will be provided to local agencies if determined by the Commission on State Mandates.
